A first commit on the same PR, or open a new PR?

Either is fine. Usually I'd just make it a first commit in the same PR -- we often merge prefixes of PRs that are independently correct, and it involves less Git logistics for you to not have the same code appear in two PRs.
Ah neat, I didn't know you can merge prefixes of PRs!

You do it manually from the Git command line. It’s not a concept GitHub knows about, so it has some disadvantages. GitHub doesn’t remember the association between the merged commits and the PR they came from, and the PR usually ends up showing as having conflicts in the GitHub UI.

A version of this was was deployed on chat.zulip.org just now. This experiment is pretty important in terms of our design direction for the compose box, so I'd appreciate folks being pretty chatty with feedback on it.

(Both how you feel about the compose box visuals, and also comment if you find yourself using it!).
Ah just noticed there's a bit of a jump of the top line of the box when switching between the two.
I personally don't think I'd use this much, but I'm curious to see if I do and also to see what others think!

I'm not sure how much I'd use this feature, but it'd definitely be useful to avoid a copy/paste, where you decide to switch audience after having typed the content. It feels more slick being integrated into the UI, and I do like how it holds the alternate recipient details if you change your mind - though that won't persist to eg. drafts, presumably, but just the compose box state?

From a design logic viewpoint, I think it would be clearer if the new button was more visually associated with the recipient header, ie. that it applies to that only, and doesn't modify the content. With limited space I'm not sure if it's possible, but having two different icons that are toggled (and eg. bold/not-bold) might make it even clearer what's possible and is happening?

In a related way (or next step), I would really enjoy the 'preview' button being next to the content, indicating that it applies to the entire content. I always thought the preview button was buried in the rest of the buttons at the bottom and can never dig out it or the 'back to editing' button that easily. It doesn't really fit with most of what the rest of the icons do.

I mentioned above about how two icons and switching highlighting of them would be good if there were space, for PM/stream. Maybe an alternative would be to have grey/highlighted icons for stream/PM at eg. corners, and switching the highlight when toggling?

That makes it a redundant identifier of which context one is located while browsing the webapp. Maybe redundancy is a good idea after all? I can infer my context via multiple cues: the description in the search bar, the URL path, and the message box descriptor. But often times, to tell whether I am in a stream/topic narrow, I have to deduce from the URL path.

Neil Pilgrim (neiljp) I didn't quite follow this part -- could you explain in more detail what you mean? Where would the icons go?

Maybe an alternative would be to have grey/highlighted icons for stream/PM at eg. corners, and switching the highlight when toggling?

To clarify:

  • The envelope icon doesn't visually signify the type of composition; it doesn't change icon when clicked, and it's unclear to me that would be better, since should the icon show the current state or the state to switch to (like the preview button does)?
  • An alternative is two icons for PM/stream, one marked 'active', the other clickable to convert to the other type of message - but this would likely take up too much space
  • Rein suggested modifying the envelope icon, which I think would be good in general, but it also made me think of a combination of the first and second points. Rather than two icons, this would be one icon, but with smaller overlays representing the active and alternate state. I originally thought of something simple like the status corner dot planned to overlay on user profile pictures in the user list, but eg. in two corners, but it could overlay more of the base icon.
I'm still curious if people have been using this feature and if people are finding it useful

I still absolutely think we should have this feature, but I actually ended up using it less than I expected. I think that's because after months of struggling with sending PMs, I eventually trained myself to use the x hotkey.

But if other folks also did not end up using the switcher frequently, that probably argues against using lots of UI space/attention to represent it, like the UI direction here.

compose-01-02-1.png
I think part of it is that none of the other community chat platforms I use allows you to switch, so I'm very used to a workflow of going to the place I want to send the message before I send it

I actually ended up in a situation where I could have used this feature, and wrote up a summary with ideas of followups, but it got very long so didn't finish the draft yet. I hope to post it soon, though might post to a different topic with the main points and link to it from here.

OK, see small essay at #design > Reply feels safe behavior. Essentially I think the concept of what was deployed was great, and it's certainly an improvement compared to now. However, if we want to gently nudge/support users to use integrated features rather than copy/paste, more is necessary.
